private_information: Can only pick up and place blocks labeled with vowels: A, E, I
Can hold at most one block at a time
Cannot place a block onto a block that is currently being held by any agent
agent_vowel.goal: Contribute to achieving the target two-stack configuration while obeying vowel-only access and holding constraints.

private_information: Can only pick up and place blocks labeled with consonants: B, C, D, F, G
Can hold at most one block at a time
Cannot place a block onto a block that is currently being held by any agent
agent_consonant.goal: Contribute to achieving the target two-stack configuration while obeying consonant-only access and holding constraints.

orchestrator.goal: Coordinate agent_vowel and agent_consonant by producing a PDDL domain and problem that enforces all access, holding, stacking, and stack-count constraints to reach the specified final stacks.

public_information: There are eight blocks: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, I
Only the top block of a nonempty stack can be picked
A held block cannot receive another block placed on top of it
A held block can be placed on any stack top or on the table to start a new stack
At most 3 stacks may exist on the table at any time
Agent_vowel may only interact with vowel blocks {A, E, I}
Agent_consonant may only interact with consonant blocks {B, C, D, F, G}
Each agent can hold at most one block at a time

orchestrator.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent PDDL modeling. You will be given the environment initial state, the global goal, and private constraints for two agents (vowel-only and consonant-only). Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that models the two-agent block-stacking task. The domain must include separate actions for each agent (e.g., pick-vowel, place-vowel, pick-consonant, place-consonant) and enforce: top-only picking, single-block holding per agent, cannot place onto a block that is currently held, vowel/consonant access restrictions, and a global constraint that no more than 3 stacks may exist at any time. Represent stacks and table positions so the goal stacks (exact ordering bottom-to-top) can be specified. Ensure actions clearly indicate which agent performs them, and do not make assumptions beyond the provided information.
orchestrator.prompt:
Your name is orchestrator.
Initial information about the environment: {environment->init}.
Goal for the environment: {environment->goal}.
The public information is: {environment->public_information}.
The agent_vowel's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->agent_vowel->private_information}.
The agent_consonant's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->agent_consonant->private_information}.
Think step by step and provide a PDDL domain and problem that encapsulate the integrated model, respecting the constraints of each agent. Do not make assumptions beyond the given information. There is no need for anything else beyond producing the pddl files.
